critiques.text:
Comment 1
The expected standard is that text should be easily readable and understandable.
In the current design, the text is small and lacks weight, hindering readability.
To fix this, increase the text size and weight to enhance readability.

Comment 2
The expected standard is to have a well-organized layout with clear information hierarchy, facilitating easy navigation and quick access to desired information.
In the current design, the elements are scattered and unorganized, leading to difficulty in locating pertinent information and hindering efficient navigation. 
To fix this, a redesign should prioritize organizing elements cohesively, implementing a clear information hierarchy, and optimizing whitespace usage for improved visual clarity.

Comment 3
The expected standard is to maintain a clean, focused design with clear hierarchy and minimal elements, resolving clutter issues for improved user comprehension and engagement.
In the current design,  there's an overabundance of elements leading to clutter, hindering user understanding and engagement with the page's purpose.
To fix this, streamline the design by prioritizing essential content, optimizing white space, and establishing a clear visual hierarchy, ensuring a more user-friendly and comprehensible interface.

Comment 4
The expected standard is that the page maintains visual balance through evenly distributed elements and clear hierarchy.
In the current design, the visual weight distribution lacks balance, leading to an unappealing layout.
To fix this, a redesign focusing on implementing a structured grid system and establishing a clear hierarchy.

Comment 5
The expected standard is that the header and body sections should feature distinct background colors or visual cues for clear differentiation, enhancing usability and visual hierarchy.
In the current design, the header and body sections share the same background color, causing confusion as they appear merged and difficult to distinguish from each other.
To fix this, implement separate background colors or distinct visual cues for the header and body sections, ensuring clear differentiation and improving user experience.

Comment 6
The expected standard is that the text should be readable and easy to understand.
In the current design, the text is small and difficult to read. 
To fix this, the text should be increased in size.

Comment 7
The expected standard is that the elements on the page should be aligned and organized in a way that is visually appealing and easy to understand. In the current design, the elements are scattered and unorganized, making it difficult to find the information that you are looking for. To fix this, the elements should be aligned and organized in a way that is more visually appealing and easier to understand.

Comment 8
The expected standard is that the design should be simple and easy to understand. In the current design, there are too many elements and the design is too cluttered, making it difficult to understand what the purpose of the page is. To fix this, the design should be simplified and the number of elements should be reduced.

Comment 9
The expected standard is that the page should be balanced in terms of its visual weight. In the current design, the page is unbalanced in terms of its visual weight.
To fix this,  the visual weight of the page should be balanced.

Comment 1
The expected standard is to make the most important information visually dominant.
In the current design, the back button is not visually prominent.
To fix this, we can enlarge the back button.

In the current design, elements lack responsiveness, clarity in clickability, and proper alignment, diminishing its professional standard.
To fix this, implement responsive design principles, enhance visual cues for clickability, and ensure proper alignment within the layout.

Comment 4
The expected standard is that each section—header, body, and footer—features unique background textures or colors, facilitating easy differentiation and improving overall visual appeal and usability.
In the current design, the lack of distinction between the header, body, and footer sections due to shared background textures detracts from visual clarity and makes it difficult for users to differentiate between the various parts of the layout.
To fix this, assign distinct background textures or colors to the header, body, and footer sections. This differentiation will enhance visual hierarchy and improve user navigation by clearly delineating each section.

Comment 5

The expected standard is to have a footer with menu icons/buttons to enhance functionality, navigation and user accessibility within the layout. 
In the current design, the absence of a footer containing menu icons/buttons undermines navigation and user interaction, hindering overall usability and functionality.

In the current design, the lack of a three-dot icon limits discoverability of hidden features and functionalities.
To fix this, add a well-placed three-dot icon for intuitive access to hidden features.

Comment 7
The expected standard is that the design utilizes space efficiently, with minimal irrelevant blank space, for a visually appealing layout.
In the current design,  it suffers from  irrelevant blank space throughout the layout. This creates a sense of emptiness and reduces the visual appeal of the interface.
To fix this,  restructure content or add visuals to eliminate dead space and enhance visual appeal.

The expected standard is that the design should be user-friendly. In the current design, the user has to click on the "Add Location" button in order to add a location. This is not user-friendly because it requires the user to take an extra step. To fix this, the "Add Location" button should be changed to a "+" button that is located in the top-right corner of the screen. This will make it easier for the user to add a location.

Comment 1
